author: Hannah Graham
title: Don't let Brexit destroy university exchange scheme, say North East Lib Dems
text:
Don't let Brexit destroy university exchange scheme, say North East Lib Dems 05:30, 13 Jul 2016 By Hannah Graham North East Liberal Democrat campaigners have launched a petition calling for the European Erasmus university exchange scheme to be protected Shares Get daily news by email Toby Melville/PA Wire The Union flag flutters next to the EU flag 
Lib Dem campaigners have called for an EU exchange programme to be protected for hundreds of North East students when the terms of Brexit are negotiated. 
North East Liberal Democrats have backed a petition calling on Government and EU leaders to preserve the Erasmus exchange scheme, which allows UK students to spend a year of their degrees studying abroad, during the upcoming negotiations over the new relationship between Britain and Europe. 
More than 20,000 UK students have studied abroad using the Erasmus scheme each year since 2007. 
Around 120,000 more were expected to use the programme between now and 2020. 
Young people going on the scheme receive free tuition and a monthly grant of around £240 to help with living costs. Separate schemes also give young people in vocational training the opportunity to do apprenticeships abroad. Lib Dem councillor Wendy Taylor 
Newcastle Lib Dem spokesperson Coun Dr Wendy Taylor said: “Thousands of students starting university in the North East’s five universities and a number of colleges in September will be hoping for the chance to take part in this scheme. 
“Young people overwhelmingly voted remain in the EU and it would be wrong to deprive them of this once in a lifetime opportunity to study or train abroad. 
“The philosopher Erasmus said 500 years ago 'I am a citizen of the world'. 
“Today’s students were born as citizens of the UK and the EU, and the 21st century economy demands that we continue to produce highly-skilled young people with experience of other languages and countries. 
“The Liberal Democrats are calling on the government and EU leaders to confirm that they will be to access the Erasmus scheme whatever happens next.” Read More EU referendum: How will Brexit affect North East universities? 
After the referendum result was announced, North East universities were quick to reassure students that nothing would immediately change for EU nationals studying in the region, or home students currently using the Erasmus scheme. 
In the long term, it is not clear how the scheme will be affected by Brexit, but some non-EU countries are currently involved. 
These include Turkey, Iceland and Norway. More on the EU Referendum
